At 00:03 08/08/2005, you wrote:
>Colin,
>
>You wrote:
>  > It occured to me that real world neural nets exist in 3D due to
>physical constr[ai]nts - there are only 3 spa[t]ial dimensions!
>
>I have not studied the biology of neurons enough to be very confident of
>this speculation.  I think *time* might be another dimension of physical
>neurons.  In other words, there are likely nuances in a physical
>neuron's firing and the *timing of the receptivity* of a
>related/connected neuron that had some level of influence on the
>evolution of the neurons and organ.  And therefore, likely have a
>reasonable influence on the emergent effects produced.  Which in turn
>effected the further evolution of both the neurons and organ.  A strange
>loop, so to speak.
>
>As you mention later, the neurons which are modeled in the ANNs we have
>been using in NEAT are very simple compared to physical neurons.  The
>idea that *all* the neurons activate in sequence (activation wave)
>before another activation wave begins is not very similar to nature at
>all.  However, the amount of computing capacity required to simulate the
>highly parallel, massively distributed and mildly chaotic (inherent
>noise) nature of physical neurons means it is much more difficult to
>simulate their behavior than the simple approach currently used.
>
>Haven't some experiments been done where they added the time component
>to the model and then were able to do some very sophisticated learning
>with very few neurons, compared to the simpler activation wave method?

Do you mean Spiking Neural Nets?

They're pretty neat (sic) in some ways, I had a link, just a second...

http://amygdala.sourceforge.net/understand_snn.php

or maybe better:

http://www.aiathome.com/articles/snnintro.pdf

         Ian

In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
